item.title: Project specific scripts
item.description: There are always scripts that you write to automate some mundane tasks. And then you put that script in a directory that is in your PATH. But what this does is that it pollutes your system global PATH and shows up in places you wouldn’t want it to be in. I was struggling with this issue for a while and struggling to get a proper solution. But there is a very simple and clever trick to solve this problem.

item.title: Copying files to container the generic way
item.description: This blog shows you how you can copy stuff from your host machine to the running container without the docker cp command that we usually use. Steps in text Here I have a script on the host, which looks following: #!/bin/bash tput bold echo "OS Information:" tput sgr0 echo cat /etc/os-release After running which looks like following: $ ls script.sh $ ./script.sh OS Information: NAME="Flatcar Linux by Kinvolk" ID=flatcar ID_LIKE=coreos VERSION=2079.
